comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: HMS Agamemnon was one of two Lord Nelson-class pre-dreadnought battleships launched in 1906 and completed in 1908. She was the Royal Navy's second-to-last pre-dreadnought battleship to be built, followed by her sister ship, Lord Nelson. She survived the Dardanelles campaign and was the last pre-dreadnought in existence when she was scrapped in 1927 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Agamemnon_(1906)

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: It's often said that "First Reports From a War Zone Are Always Wrong". Here's a headline from a front-page New York Times story of June 15, 1915:         ANOTHER BRITISH         BATTLESHIP SUNK;   The Agamemnon, 16,500 Tons, Went Down in Dardanelles in May.   THE SHIP WAS TORPEDOED  All the Officers and Crew Said   to Have Been Saved -- News     Suppressed in England.   The article states, "A wireless message from Berlin announcing the loss of the Agamemnon was picked up in London, but the censors would not permit its publication or transmission over the cables." Remarkably, The Times goes on to boast how they were able to get confirmation of the sinking through their "word of mouth" sources that "circulate within a limited circle" of people. The article is an interesting glimpse at the forces of possible propaganda, rumor, gossip, fear and censorship involving one country at war (England) and the U.S. which, while not yet in the war, certainly regarded it as their number-one concern.
